questions.text: Which of the following perceptual disturbances is more likely to indicate an organic etiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • If a patient presents with visual hallucination, organic mental disorders should be assessed.
  • Visual hallucinations usually indicate disturbance of occipital or temporal lobes or brainstem/reticular activating system dysfunction.
  • Common in conditions like:
    • Delirium
    • Parkinson's disease
    • Lewy body dementia
    • Charles Bonnet syndrome (visual loss-related hallucinations)
    • Drug intoxication or withdrawal (e.g., alcohol)

Explanation of other options:

  • Auditory hallucinations (Option A):More characteristic of functional psychiatric illnesses such as schizophrenia.
  • Formal thought disorder (Option B):A hallmark of schizophrenia and other primary psychotic disorders, not specifically linked to organic lesions.
  • Depression (Option D):While it can be seen in both functional and organic conditions, it is not specific enough to suggest an organic lesion.

questions.text: Maximum score in MMSE is given to which of the following cognitive functions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The MMSE is described as a 30-point cognitive test that provides a bedside assessment of a broad array of cognitive function, including orientation, attention, memory, construction, and language. The cognitive function awarded the maximum points in the MMSE is orientation.
  • MMSE assesses the following five cognitive functions and gives them different weightage.
    1. Orientation - 10 points
    2. Registration - 3 points
    3. Attention and concentration - 5 points
    4. Recall - 3 points
    5. Language - 9 points
    6. Max score = 30
    7. ≤24/30 = indicative of cognitive impairment

questions.text: A 55 year old man is admitted in hospital after 3rd degree burn with TBSA 70%. 2 days after the admission, he started forgetting incidents and was unable to recognize his family members. Suddenly he is complaining that scorpions are attacking him. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario,the 55 year old with third degree burns is having symptoms of sudden onset disorientation, visual hallucinations and memory disturbance which all points towards Acute Delirium caused may be due to metabolic disturbance.

Explanation of other options:

  • Acute Dementia(Option A):Dementia is chronic and progressive, not acute.Onset is gradual over months to years, with persistent cognitive decline.Delirium can occur in patients with dementia, but the acute onset here points away from dementia.
  • Acute Schizophrenia(Option B):Schizophrenia typically has a gradual onset and develops over weeks to months, especially in younger individuals.Hallucinations in schizophrenia are auditory, not typically visual.Does not explain the disorientation and memory loss.
  • Paranoid Personality Disorder(Option D):This is a chronic personality pattern, not an acute medical or psychiatric emergency.No hallucinations or disorientation; the person remains oriented and functional (though distrustful and suspicious).

questions.text: A patient presents with abrupt loss of reading ability despite being literate, however, when asked to write, he could write spontaneously. This can be caused due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture described is that of Alexia without Agraphia (Pure Alexia).A rare disconnection syndrome in which the patient:
    • Cannot read (alexia),
    • Can write (agraphia absent),
    • But cannot read what they have written.
  • Occurs due to damage to the dominant (usually left) occipital lobe and the splenium of the corpus callosum.The left occipital lobe processes visual input from the right visual field, and language areas (e.g., angular gyrus) are in the left hemisphere.If the splenium is damaged, visual input from the right hemisphere cannot be transferred to the language centers in the left hemisphere.Most commonly due to infarct in the left PCA (posterior cerebral artery) territory.

Explanation of other options:

  • ACA infarct(Option A):Affects medial frontal lobes, which control lower limbs, continence, and motivational behavior (abulia).Not associated with language or visual processing deficits.
  • MCA infarct(Option B):Involves lateral cerebral cortex, including Broca's and Wernicke's areas.Can cause aphasia and agraphia, but not pure alexia.Does not disconnect visual processing from language areas the way PCA infarct does.
  • PICA infarct(Option D):It causes lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg's).Symptoms include vertigo, nystagmus, loss of pain/temperature, Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: All of the following conditions result due to problems with basal ganglia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Multiple sclerosis is a demyelinating autoimmune disorder of the central nervous system. It primarily affects white matter tracts, optic nerves, cerebellum, brainstem, and spinal cord. Although MS can affect various parts of the brain, it does not primarily target the basal ganglia.
  • There are four main conditions to be aware of that result from problems with the basal ganglia: -
    • Huntington's chorea (caudate nucleus)
    • Wilson's disease (copper deposition in the basal ganglia)
    • Parkinson's disease (substantia nigra)
    • Hemiballismus (subthalamic nucleus)

Explanation of other options:

  • Parkinson's Disease(Option A):Directly involves the basal ganglia, especially the substantia nigra pars compacta.Loss of dopaminergic neurons → impaired signaling in basal ganglia circuits.Symptoms: bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, postural instability.
  • Huntington's Disease(Option B):A genetic neurodegenerative disorder.Targets the caudate nucleus and putamen (part of the basal ganglia).Leads to chorea, psychiatric symptoms, dementia.Clear example of basal ganglia pathology.
  • Wilson's Disease(Option D):Autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism.Copper deposits in liver, basal ganglia, cornea, etc.Basal ganglia (especially putamen and globus pallidus) are heavily affected.Leads to movement disorders, psychiatric symptoms, cognitive decline

questions.text: This syndrome presents with affected individuals being cortically blind but unaware of it and hence deny they have a problem. Patients start falling over furniture as they can't see. However, they believe they can still see and describe their environments in detail but are wrong in their description. Identify this syndrome.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anton's syndrome (Anton-Babinski syndrome):

  • Occurs following damage to the occipital lobe.
  • Affected individuals are cortically blind but are unaware of this and deny they have a problem (Anosognosia). It often presents as the patient starts falling over furniture as they can't see. Affected individuals believe they can still see and describe their environments in detail but are wrong in their description (confabulation).

Explanation of other options:

  • Wallenberg Syndrome(Option A):It is also called lateral medullary syndrome, caused by PICA infarct.
    • Features:Vertigo, dysphagia, Horner's syndrome, contralateral body loss of pain/temp, ipsilateral face loss of pain/temp.
  • Gerstmann Syndrome(Option B):Caused by lesion in the dominant (usually left) inferior parietal lobe (angular gyrus).Classic tetrad:
    1. Agraphia
    2. Acalculia
    3. Finger agnosia
    4. Left-right disorientation
    5. Blindness or denial of blindness is not seen.
  • Balint Syndrome(Option C):Caused by bilateral parietal-occipital lesions.Triad includes:
    1. Optic ataxia (difficulty reaching for objects)
    2. Oculomotor apraxia (difficulty shifting gaze)
    3. Simultanagnosia (can't perceive more than one object at a time)

questions.text: Abnormal prion protein (PrPSc) is seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Prion diseases:

  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
  • Kuru
  • Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker syndrome
  • Fatal familial insomnia
  • Prions are infectious agents composed of protein. Prions are made of proteins called PrP.
  • PrP exists in a normal form (PrPc) and an abnormal form (PrPSc).
  • PrPSc is resistant to protease and therefore cannot be broken down in the body.
  • PrPSc can change adjacent PrPc into PrPSc (this is how the 'infection' spreads).

questions.text: Which metabolite is found in low concentrations in CSF of one third of patients with depression and suicidal patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Serotonin metabolite called 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is found in low concentrations in the CSF of up to a third of people with depression and very few normal controls.(Option A,C&D ruled out)
  • People with low CSF levels of 5-HIAA have also been found to respond less well to antidepressants and also to be more likely to commit suicide.
  • Low levels of 5-HIAA are also associated with increased levels of aggression.

choices.text: A: I, B: III, C: V, D: IV, E: II
A: IV, B: I, C: II, D: V, E: III
A: III, B: V, C: II, D: I, E: IV
A: III, B: I, C: V, D: II, E: IV

questions.text: Match the following structures of brain to their presumed functions
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Prefrontal Cortex → Executive functions
    • Responsible for planning, decision-making, working memory, and goal-directed behavior.
  • Orbitofrontal Cortex → Impulsivity
    • Involved in inhibition, emotional regulation, and decision-making; damage leads to disinhibition and impulsivity.
  • Supramarginal Gyrus → Visuospatial attention
    • Part of the parietal lobe; integrates visual, tactile, and spatial information; crucial for attention orientation.
  • Planum Temporale → Language and music
    • Located in the superior temporal gyrus; larger on the left; associated with language processing and musical ability.
  • Insula → Taste
    • Primary gustatory cortex; processes taste, visceral sensation, and emotional awareness.

choices.text: A: I, B: II, C: III, D: IV, E: V
A: II, B: III, C: I, D: IV, E: V
A: II, B: I, C: III, D: V, E: IV
A: II, B: I, C: III, D: IV, E: V

questions.text: Match the following neurotransmitters to their areas of synthesis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cell bodies of these serotonergic neurons are clustered in the midline raphe nuclei of the brainstem.
  • Dopamine neurons are more widely distributed than those of other monoamines, residing in the midbrain substantia nigra and ventral tegmental area and in the periaqueductal gray, hypothalamus, olfactory bulb, and retina.
  • Norepinephrine-producing neurons are found within the brain in the pons and medulla in two major clusterings: The locus coeruleus (LC) and the lateral tegmental noradrenergic nuclei.
  • Histaminergic cell bodies are located within a region of the posterior hypothalamus termed the tuberomammillary nucleus.
  • Two large clusters of cholinergic projection neurons are found within the brain: The basal forebrain complex and the mesopontine complex.

questions.text: Bonding refers to the relationship formed by a mother for her child. Which of the following hormones is responsible for bonding behaviour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oxytocin is implicated in mammalian bonding behaviour, particularly in the initiation and maintenance of maternal behaviour, social bonding, and sexual receptivity.
  • Oxytocin is theorized to be released during orgasm, more so in women than in men, and is presumed to promote bonding between the sexes.
  • It has been used in autistic children experimentally in an attempt to increase socialization.

choices.text: 80% of this neurotransmitter is available in brain
This neurotransmitter is synthesized from amino acid tyrosine
This neurotransmitter is degraded by Monoamine Oxidase
Amino acid required for synthesis of this neurotransmitter is not available from diet

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with a depressed mood, lack of interest and death wishes. Which of the following statements is true regarding the major neurotransmitter implicated in causation of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The major neurotransmitter implicated in causation of depressive symptoms is low levels of serotonin.
  • The CNS contains less than 2 percent of the serotonin in the body. More than 80 percent of all the serotonin in the body is found in the gastrointestinal system, where it modulates motility and digestive functions.
  • Serotonin is synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan, which is derived from the diet.
  • The first step in the degradation of serotonin is mediated by monoamine oxidase type A (MAOA), which oxidizes the amino group to form an aldehyde.

choices.text: APOE4 allele increases the risk of dementia in his condition
PSEN-1 gene increases the risk of dementia in his condition
PSEN-2 gene increases the risk of dementia in his condition
APP gene increases the risk of dementia in his condition

questions.text: A 66-year-old male presents with non-traumatic chronic progressive decline in memory. Which of the following statements holds true about dementia genetics?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the above question, late onset Alzheimer's disease (age of onset > 65 years) is associated with presence of apoE4 allele.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with a 12-year history of persecutory delusions and hallucinations, along with episodes of mania and depression in between. He was diagnosed with schizoaffective disorder. His relatives would have increased risk for developing most of the following psychiatric disorders except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Although alcohol use disorder (AUD) may co-occur with psychiatric illnesses, especially mood or psychotic disorders, it is not genetically linked to schizoaffective disorder.Family members of schizoaffective patients are not at increased genetic risk specifically for alcohol use disorder.
  • AUD has its own genetic and environmental risk profile, distinct from the schizoaffective-schizophrenia-bipolar spectrum.

Genetics of Schizoaffective disorder:

  • The risk to first-degree relatives for ANY psychiatric disorder is higher in SA disorder than any other psychiatric disorder. The extent of heritability is unclear, although likely in the range of schizophrenia.
  • Relatives have a higher rate of schizoaffective illness, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.
  • The rate of bipolar disorder is high if the proband has a schizoaffective-manic presentation. The rate of schizophrenia is high if proband has schizoaffective-depressive presentation. In the depressive subtype no elevation in bipolar risk has been noted in a large cohort.

choices.text: A: III, B: V, C: II, D: I, E: IV
A: I, B: V, C: IV, D: III, E: II
A: II, B: IV, C: III, D: I, E: V
A: IV, B: V, C: II, D: I, E: III

questions.text: Match the following disorders to the genes implicated in their causation

A 56-year-old man presents with talkativeness, hyperactivity, hyper-religiosity, and grandiose delusions, including hallucinations of God telling him he is omnipotent. He had suffered a stroke 4 months ago.These behavioral and psychiatric disturbances are most likely due to involvement of which of the following brain regions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Post-stroke mania is a rare manifestation after stroke.
  • Either cortical (baso-temporal cortex or orbitofrontal cortex) or subcortical (frontal white matter, basal ganglia, or thalamus). [Most common lesion in mania: Right Baso-temporal cortex]
  • Baso-temporal cortex has strong efferent connections to the orbitofrontal
  • Combination of biogenic amine dysfunction and release of tonic inhibitory input to orbitofrontal-thalamic circuit may lead to production of mania.

Explanation of other options:

  • Left-sided cortical(Option A):Likely results in aphasia, depression, or anxiety, but rarely in hyper-religiosity or grandiose religious delusions.
  • Left-sided subcortical(Option B):May cause apathy or mood crises, but not typically manic-like, hyper-religious, or talkative psychosis.
  • Right-sided subcortical(Option D):May lead to mood lability and pseudobulbar affect, but cortical involvement is needed for grandiose religious delusions or hyperreligiosity.

questions.text: It was observed that few patients, in their post-stroke period, developed emotional out-bursts that seemed inappropriate to the situation. Few of them became easily agitated, hostile and refused to cooperate with the family members or with the physicians. Such symptoms would be precipitated by minor events and were quite distressing for the care-givers. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As in the clinical scenario discussed,it was observed that few patients, in their post-stroke period, developed:
    • Emotional outbursts inappropriate to the situation
    • Became easily agitated, hostile
    • Refused to cooperate with family and doctors
    • Symptoms triggered by minor events
    • Distressing for caregivers
  • Kurt Goldstein first described catastrophic reactions in post-stroke patients, reporting that it is the inability to cope when faced with a serious defect in physical or cognitive functions of a person.

Clinical features:

  • Sudden outbursts of intense emotional reaction like anxiety, tears, aggressive behaviour, swearing, displacement, refusal, renouncement, and/or sometimes compensatory boasting.
  • Provoked by stressful situations
  • Typically subsides within a few minutes.

Commonly associated comorbidities: Depression and anxiety

Etiology:

  • Lesions involving basal ganglia
  • Anterior lesions
  • Lesions primarily located in subcortical regions.

Explanation of other options:

  • Akinetic mutism(Option A):It is characterized by lack of speech (mutism) and lack of movement (akinesia) despite preserved alertness.Seen in bilateral frontal lobe lesions or damage to the cingulate gyrus.No emotional outbursts the patient is apathetic and unresponsive, not hostile or agitated.
  • Pathological emotions(Option B):Refers to pseudobulbar affect, where the patient has involuntary episodes of laughing or crying that are inappropriate to context.Not typically hostile or uncooperative.Associated with bilateral upper motor neuron lesions (e.g., ALS, multiple sclerosis, strokes).
  • Catatonic reaction(Option D):A psychomotor disturbance seen in severe psychiatric illnesses like schizophrenia or mood disorders.Includes motor immobility, mutism, negativism, waxy flexibility, etc.Not typical in post-stroke emotional instability.

questions.text: In post-stroke patients who exhibit spontaneous laughing or crying with minimal provocation, the condition is known by all of the following terms except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pathological laughter/ crying is defined as laughing and/or crying occurring spontaneously or after some seemingly minor provocation.
  • Indicative of underlying depression. It is seen in the post-stroke period.
  • Other names: Emotional incontinence, emotional lability, pseudobulbar effect, pathological emotionalism, involuntary emotional expression disorder.

Explanation of other options:

  • Pathological laughter/crying(Option B):Describes involuntary and emotional outbursts (laughing or crying) that do not match the emotional context.It is the older, non-technical term for spontaneous emotional expression after neurological injury.
  • Pseudobulbar effect (also called pseudobulbar affect)(Option C):A common and well-recognized consequence of bilateral corticobulbar or brainstem damage (e.g., after stroke), leading to involuntary, uncontrollable laughing or crying .
  • Emotional incontinence(Option D):Another synonymous term used to describe this phenomenon-patients have impaired control over emotional expression, causing frequent, context-inappropriate outbursts .

questions.text: Gastaut Geschwind syndrome refers to a group of personality traits developing in a patient with epilepsy. These traits include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gestaut Geschwind syndrome:

  • The interictal behaviour syndrome in temporal lobe epilepsy also known as Gastaut–Geschwind syndrome is characterized by Group of traits in some patients with focal dyscognitive seizures
  • Temporal Lobe focus
  • Heightened significance of thingsSerious, humourless, over inclusive & circumstantial speech - viscous(Option D ruled out)
  • Increased philosophical interest(Option A ruled out)
  • Hypergraphia(Option C ruled out)
  • Hypo sexuality

choices.text: There is less social withdrawal as compared to schizophrenia
Delusions are less systematized as compared to schizophrenia
More religiosity is observed in inter-ictal psychosis
There are more negative symptoms in inter-ictal psychosis

questions.text: In a patient of epilepsy, you would differentiate psychosis developing in inter-ictal period from schizophrenia by all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Inter-ictal psychosis is a chronic psychotic state that can develop in patients with long-standing epilepsy, especially temporal lobe epilepsy.
  • Schizophrenia is characterized by prominent negative symptoms such as:
    • Affective flattening
    • Alogia (poverty of speech)
    • Avolition (lack of motivation)
  • These are generally milder or absent in inter-ictal psychosis, where positive symptoms predominate (delusions, hallucinations).

Characteristics of inter-ictal psychosis:

  • Paranoia with sudden onset
  • Preserved affective warmth
  • No personality deterioration
  • Less social withdrawal than schizophrenia
  • Less systematised delusions
  • More hallucinations and affective symptoms
  • More religiosity
  • Positive > negative symptoms

Explanation of other options:

  • Social withdrawal is less prominent in inter-ictal psychosis(Option A):Patients with inter-ictal psychosis tend to remain more socially connected than patients with schizophrenia.Schizophrenia is marked by marked social withdrawal, a core negative symptom.
  • Delusions are less systematized(Option B):In inter-ictal psychosis, delusions are often vague, poorly systematized, and bizarre, sometimes with religious or persecutory themes, but less organized than in classic schizophrenia.
  • Greater religiosity is common(option C):This is a classic feature of inter-ictal psychosis. Patients often show hyperreligiosity, philosophical interests, or mystical experiences, especially in temporal lobe epilepsy (linked to the Geschwind syndrome).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man diagnosed with a brain tumor is reported by his family to have developed marked personality changes. He has become disinhibited, frequently exhibits explosive outbursts, and makes sexually inappropriate remarks. Which of the following is the most likely location of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The frontal lobe, particularly the orbitofrontal cortex, is responsible for:
    • Personality regulation
    • Social behavior
    • Impulse control
    • Emotional regulation
  • Tumors or lesions in this area can lead to:
    • Disinhibition
    • Aggressive or explosive behavior
    • Sexually inappropriate actions
    • Lack of insight or judgment
  • Bilateral lesions of the frontal lobes are characterized by changes in personality-how persons interact with the world.
  • The frontal lobe syndrome, which is most commonly produced by trauma, infarcts, tumors, lobotomy, multiple sclerosis, or Pick's disease, consists of slowed thinking, poor judgment, decreased curiosity, social withdrawal, and irritability.
  • Patients typically display apathetic indifference to experience that can suddenly explode into impulsive disinhibition.

Explanation of other options:

  • Temporal lobe(Option B):Involved in memory, emotional processing, and auditory perception; lesions may cause memory disturbances or complex partial seizures.
  • Parietal lobe(Option C):Deals with spatial orientation and sensory integration; damage may cause neglect or apraxia.
  • Occipital lobe(Option D):Primarily involved in visual processing; lesions typically lead to visual field defects or hallucinations.

questions.text: Which of the following terms describes personality changes occurring after traumatic brain injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pseudo-psychopathic personality change arises from damage to the orbitofrontal cortex, particularly the ventromedial prefrontal region.
  • Clinical features include disinhibition, impulsivity, aggression, poor insight, hypersexuality, and antisocial behaviors closely resembling psychopathy but with an organic cause.
  • Pseudo-depressed personality is another post TBI personality change characterised by apathy and blunted affect

Explanation of other options:

  • Pseudo-anxious (Option A):Not a commonly recognized syndrome post-TBI.Anxiety after brain injury is typically classified under secondary anxiety disorders, not "pseudo-anxious" personality alteration.
  • Pseudo-psychotic(Option C):"Pseudo-psychosis" occurs in some organic conditions but refers to hallucinatory or delusional presentations, not to personality change.Personality post-TBI would not be labeled "pseudo-psychotic" unless there are clear psychotic symptoms.
  • Pseudo-manic(Option D):personality change,Mania-like behaviors can emerge after TBI, but "pseudo-manic" personality changes are less well-defined and would instead typically be described as secondary mania or organic mood disorder.

choices.text: Not aggravated by noise or light
Not associated with nausea or vomiting

questions.text: In a patient presenting with headache, all of the following features typically suggest tension-type headache except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tension-type headache is the most common type of primary headache and has characteristic features that help distinguish it from migraine or cluster headache.

Criteria for Tension type headache:

  • At least 10 episodes of headache occurring on 1-14 days per month on average for >3 months and,
  • 1 attack lasting from 30 mins-7 days.
  • 2/4 of following
    • Bilateral non-pulsatile (non-throbbing quality)(Option A and Option B ruled out), mild to moderate, not aggravated by routine activities
  • None of following
    • Nausea or vomiting, either photo or phono-phobia.(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with a depressed mood for 6 months, along with lethargy, poor sleep, decreased energy, difficulty concentrating, and unintentional weight gain (>15 lb). She also reports easy bruising. Examination reveals purple abdominal striae, proximal muscle weakness, and bitemporal hemianopia. MRI shows a brain tumor.In which area of the brain is the tumor most likely located?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tumours of the pituitary cause bi-temporal hemi-anopsia by compressing the optic chiasm and a variety of endocrine disturbances that in turn can cause psychiatric symptoms.
  • The woman in the question has a basophilic adenoma, and her depression is part of her Cushing syndrome.
  • Patients with Craniopharyngiomas can also present with behavioural and autonomic disturbances caused by the upward extension of the tumour into the diencephalon.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with moodiness, irritability, and angry outbursts. He describes "spells" where he experiences olfactory hallucinations (e.g., the smell of rotten eggs and burning rubber) and a feeling of derealization. MRI reveals a brain tumor.In which brain region is the tumor most likely located?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario,A 26-year-old man presents with mood changes (moody, irritable),severe angry outbursts,olfactory hallucinations (smelling rotten eggs and burning rubber),depersonalization-like episodes ("feels like in a dream") and his MRI reveals a brain tumor, these symptoms points towards a lesion in the temporal lobe.
  • Tumours of the temporal lobe can present with olfactory and other unusual types of hallucinations, derealization episodes, mood lability, irritability, intermittent anger, and behavioural decontrol.
  • Anxiety is another frequent finding.

Explanation of other options:

  • Frontal Lobe(Option A):Involved in executive functions, personality, and impulse control.Tumors may cause disinhibition or apathy, but olfactory hallucinations are not typical.Can cause behavioral changes but not the specific "spells" and sensory auras described.
  • Parietal Lobe(Option B):Involved in sensory integration, spatial orientation, and body image.Lesions may lead to neglect, agraphesthesia, apraxia.Not associated with olfactory auras or depersonalization.
  • Occipital Lobe(Option C): It Controls visual processing.Tumors or lesions here may cause visual hallucinations, hemianopia, or visual agnosia.No involvement with mood changes or olfaction.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old man presents with nervousness, excitability, and persistent fear of impending death for the past 3 months. He describes this as a dramatic change from his usual relaxed self. He reports a 20 lb weight loss, frequent diarrhea, and on exam, has pressured speech, fine tremor, and tachycardia.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the patient is having symptoms of nervousness, excitability, constant anxiety for 3 months, sudden fear of impending death (panic-like episodes)significant weight loss, frequent diarrhea and on mental status exam pressured speech was observed with physical examination showing fine tremor and tachycardia. All these points are most probably favouring hyperthyroidism as the diagnosis.
  • Hyperthyroidism is a metabolic-endocrine disorder that often mimics psychiatric illness, particularly anxiety disorders, panic attacks, and mania.
  • Patients with hyperthyroidism complain of heat intolerance and excessive sweating, as well as diarrhoea, weight loss, tachycardia, palpitations, and vomiting.
  • Psychiatric complaints can include nervousness, excitability, irritability, pressured speech, insomnia, psychosis, and a fear of impending death or doom.
  • Decreased concentration, hyperactivity, and a fine tremor may also be found.

Explanation of other options:

  • Hypothyroidism(Option B): It causes slowing of mental and physical activity, fatigue, depression, weight gain, constipation, bradycardia. Opposite of this patient's symptoms.May mimic depression, not mania/anxiety.
  • Hepatic Encephalopathy(Option C): Has features of confusion, altered consciousness, asterixis, ammonia elevation.Typically not associated with anxiety, tremors, or weight loss
  • Hyperparathyroidism(Option D): The Classic symptoms: bones, stones, groans, and psychic overtones.May cause fatigue, depression, apathy, but not tremors, diarrhea, or pressure of speech. Hypercalcemia symptoms will be more pronounced.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man admitted in an intensive care unit suddenly develops fluctuation in orientation to time, place and person along with sleeplessness, aggressive behaviour and visualisation of small insects and animals. All of the following terms can be used to describe his condition except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above-mentioned case scenario represents delirium. Various terms describing delirium are as follows:

  • Acute confusional state
  • Acute brain failure(Option A ruled out)
  • Encephalitis
  • Encephalopathy
  • Intensive care unit psychosis
  • Toxic metabolic state
  • Central nervous system toxicity
  • Paraneoplastic limbic encephalitis
  • Sundowning
  • Cerebral insufficiency(Option B ruled out)
  • Organic brain syndrome(Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male suffering from a mental health condition presents with acute onset of fluctuating orientation, confusion, hearing of fearful voices, trying to run out of the house over 3-4 days. Which of the following causes pertaining to psychiatry is least responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Some causes pertaining to psychiatry that can lead to development of a delirious state are as follows:

  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Serotonin syndrome
  • Electroconvulsive therapy(Option B ruled out)
  • Substance use (intoxication and withdrawal)
  • Medications: high doses of mood stabilisers (Valproate, lithium)(Option A Ruled out), antipsychotics (olanzapine), benzodiazepines, anticholinergic agents
  • Disorders: Schizophrenia (due to poor self-care leading to nutritional deficiency), Bulimia nervosa (metabolic derangements due to frequent vomiting)(Option C ruled out).

Obsessive compulsive disorder is rarely implicated in causing delirium.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman recently operated for a fracture of femur around two days' back presents with episodes of getting disoriented, behaving as if she is at her native village, remaining sleepy, stuporous and giving sluggish responses. Which of the following types of acute confusional state describes her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In hypoactive delirium, the individual has a hypoactive level of psychomotor activity that may be accompanied by sluggishness and lethargy that approaches stupor. As in this case the 66 year old is lethargic,sluggish speech,minimal motor activity etc.

Explanation of other options:

  • Hyperactive Delirium(Option A):The patient with delirium will have features of Agitation, restlessness,Hallucinations, aggression,Tachycardia, sweating and More dramatic and easier to recognize.
  • Mixed Delirium(Option C):Fluctuates between hyperactive and hypoactive features.May be alert/agitated at times and withdrawn at others.Does not match the constantly lethargic picture in this case.

choices.text: Delirium presents with fairly consistent level of attention, while dementia presents with fluctuating levels of attention.
Time to development of symptoms is short and sudden onset in delirium, while it is gradual and insidious in dementia
Cognitive impairment occurs for remote memory in delirium, while it is for recent and immediate memory in dementia

questions.text: Which of the following clinical characteristics helps differentiate delirious conditions in an already demented patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Delirium is acute onset, develops over hours to days and Dementia a chronic, progressive, insidious onset takes over months and years to manifest.This is one of the most reliable clinical differentiators between the two.

Explanation of other options:

  • Delirium presents with a fairly consistent level of attention, while dementia presents with fluctuating levels of attention(Option A):In delirium, attention is impaired and fluctuating, often waxing and waning during the day.In dementia, attention is typically preserved until late stages, and fluctuations are less dramatic than in delirium.
  • Cognitive impairment occurs for remote memory in delirium, while it is for recent and immediate memory in dementia(option C):In delirium, short-term memory and attention are affected most, but not necessarily remote memory.

In dementia, especially Alzheimer's, recent and immediate memory are impaired first, and remote memory is spared until late.

questions.text: A 42-year-old manic patient put on electroconvulsive therapy and started on high dosage of Sodium Valproate, Olanzapine and Benzodiazepines presents with acute confused state since last 2 days. Which of the following methods of non-pharmacological management would help in improving his clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient is presenting with delirium or an acute confusional state, likely secondary to a combination of:
    • High-dose psychotropic medication (Valproate, Olanzapine, Benzodiazepines),
    • Recent ECT,
    • Possibly underlying medical or metabolic causes.

Non-pharmacological management in delirium:

  • Modification of surroundings:
    • To maximise safety
    • To decrease fear and agitation
    • Adequate sensory stimulation, like providing eyeglasses and hearing aids to those impaired, providing paper and pencil for communication, room with a window view to provide orientation
    • Avoiding extremes of sensory input, e.g., avoiding sensory overstimulation in a loud and busy hospital unit or sensory deprivation in an isolated, dark, windowless room.
  • Maintaining normal sleep-wake cycle by promoting use of daytime activity and environmental cues (such as windows and clocks)
  • Adequate nutrition
  • Psychosocial support
  • Frequent reorientation to time, place, person, familiar surroundings.

Explanation of other options:

  • Sensory Overstimulation(Option A):Increases agitation and confusion in delirium.Bright lights, loud sounds, and chaotic environments worsen symptoms.
  • Sensory Deprivation(option B):Also contributes to delirium particularly in ICU or post-ECT settings.Lack of stimuli can worsen disorientation.
  • Physical Restraining(Option C):Should be avoided unless there's immediate danger.Can worsen agitation, increase injury risk, and cause psychological trauma.

choices.text: Rapid correction of sodium is the best option for improving his condition
Haloperidol given intravenously will decrease agitated behaviour
Haloperidol must be given intramuscularly to avoid risk of Qtc prolongation
Promethazine can be safely administered without any risk of worsening his condition

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with confused agitated behaviour and altered levels of attention over the last 7 days. The laboratory workup is suggestive of low sodium levels, 118 mEq/ L. Which of the following statements is true regarding management of his clinical state?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Haloperidol is commonly administered orally and intramuscularly in delirium for agitation. Use of intravenous haloperidol is associated with increased risk of QTc.(option B ruled out)
  • Anticholinergics like promethazine have further risk of worsening the delirious state due to decrease in levels of acetylcholine.(option D ruled out)
  • Rapid correction of sodium levels should be avoided in any condition to prevent central pontine myelinolysis.(option A ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is implicated in cerebral insufficiency caused by head trauma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cerebral insufficiency due to head trauma particularly in cases like traumatic brain injury (TBI) involves multiple neurochemical mechanisms.

Pathophysiological mechanisms involved in delirium:

  1. Neurotransmitter mechanism-
    • Decrease in levels of acetylcholine(Option A ruled out)
    • Increase in levels of dopamine (reciprocal acetylcholine-dopamine balance)(Option B ruled out)
    • Increase in glutamate levels (Excitatory neurotoxicity causing neuronal damage)(Option C ruled out)
    • Increase in GABA levels (implicated in hepatic encephalopathy, delirium secondary to benzodiazepine and alcohol withdrawal)
    • Other neurotransmitters like norepinephrine and serotonin may also have a role
  2. Inflammation (Delirium as a CNS response to systemic inflammation)-
    • Cytokines (IL-1, IL-2, IL-6, TNF-a, interferon) may contribute to delirium by increasing permeability of blood-brain-barrier and altering neurotransmission.

questions.text: A 46-year-old chronic alcoholic (heavy prolonged drinking) presents with altered sensorium, frequent disorientation, and stuporous state. Laboratory investigations show highly deranged liver enzymes. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for the encephalopathy stage in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has hepatic encephalopathy, a neuropsychiatric syndrome resulting from advanced liver disease, typically seen in chronic alcoholics.Hepatic encephalopathy (following prolonged heavy use of alcohol) has been associated with increased GABA and serum ammonia levels.
  • Liver dysfunction leads to failure in ammonia metabolism.
  • Ammonia crosses the blood-brain barrier, causing:
    • Astrocyte swelling
    • Disruption of neurotransmission
    • Cerebral edema and altered consciousness
  • Ammonia and several other factors are known to induce and aggravate astrocyte swelling that initiates a cascade of events leading to delirium.
  • In addition, elevated ammonia levels can contribute to increased glutamate and glutamine levels, which are precursors to GABA.
  • Acetylcholine plays a role in consciousness and attention, its deficiency is not a primary or proven mechanism in the pathogenesis of hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: A delirious patient is often seen to be aimlessly grasping or plucking at clothes and bedsheets. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carphologia (also known as floccillation) is a lint-picking behaviour that is a symptom of a delirious state.
  • It describes the actions of picking or grasping at imaginary objects, as well as the patient's own clothes or bed linens.

Explanation of other options:

  • Fasciculation(Option A): It is an Involuntary, fine, rapid twitching of individual muscle fibers, typically under the skin.Seen in Lower motor neuron lesions, motor neuron disease (like ALS), after fatigue or sometimes benignly.
  • Hallucination(Option C):False sensory perception (e.g., hearing voices, seeing things) without an external stimulus.Hallucinations can occur in delirium, psychosis, or substance use, but not specific to plucking behavior.
  • Formication(Option D): It is a sensation of insects crawling on or under the skin.Commonly seen in Cocaine or amphetamine intoxication, alcohol withdrawal (delirium tremens), menopause, or peripheral neuropathy.It may cause scratching but not aimless plucking like carphologia.

questions.text: In a delirious patient, disturbances in attention increase towards the evening time due to sensory deprivation. This is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a delirious state, the patient becomes more disturbed, disoriented, hyper vigilant towards the evening after sunset due to sensory deprivation and fatigue This is known as sundowning.

Explanation of other options:

  • Clouding of consciousness(Option A):Refers to a global impairment of consciousness, attention, and awareness.Seen in delirium, but it's a core symptom, not a time-specific fluctuation.
  • Twilight state(Option B):Describes an acute onset of altered consciousness, usually in epilepsy or dissociative states.Characterized by confusion, hallucinations, and amnesia for the episode.

choices.text: Clozapine is the safe antipsychotic in this condition
Use of haloperidol is associated with worsening of parkinsonian features

questions.text: In a patient having parkinsonian features presenting in a delirious state, all of the following statements hold true except;
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In Parkinson's disease, the antiparkinsonian agents are frequently implicated in causing delirium,particularly anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl, which can worsen delirium due to their central anticholinergic effects, especially in elderly patients.
  • If delirium persists after attenuation of antiparkinsonian agents, clozapine is recommended.

Explanation of other options:

  • Clozapine is the safe antipsychotic in this condition (option B):Clozapine and quetiapine are safest antipsychotics in Parkinson's disease patients when treating psychosis or delirium because they have minimal D2 receptor antagonism.They do not worsen motor symptoms significantly.However, clozapine requires monitoring for agranulocytosis.
  • Use of haloperidol is associated with worsening of parkinsonian features(Option C):Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic with strong D2 antagonism, which worsens extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) like rigidity, bradykinesia especially in Parkinson's patients.
  • Risperidone should be avoided (Option D):Risperidone, although an atypical antipsychotic, has relatively strong D2 antagonism compared to quetiapine/clozapine.It can cause or exacerbate EPS and should be avoided in Parkinson's disease patients.
